perturbation.original_text:
(a) This Agreement shall become effective as of the first date above written. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, without
the payment of any penalty, upon 60 days' written notice, by the vote of a majority of the outstanding voting securities of the Fund or by the vote
of the Fund's Trustees or by the Blockchain Administrator. The provisions of Section 5 of this Agreement shall remain in full force and effect, and
the Blockchain Administrator shall remain entitled to the benefits thereof, notwithstanding any termination of this Agreement. Further,
notwithstanding the termination or expiration of this Agreement as aforesaid, the Blockchain Administrator shall be entitled to any amounts owed
under Section 4 through the date of termination or expiration, and Section 5 shall continue in force and effect and apply to the Blockchain
Administrator and its representatives as and to the extent applicable.
perturbation.changed_text:
(a) This Agreement shall become effective as of the first date above written. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, without
the payment of any penalty, upon 10 days' written notice, by the vote of a majority of the outstanding voting securities of the Fund or by the vote
of the Fund's Trustees or by the Blockchain Administrator. The provisions of Section 5 of this Agreement shall remain in full force and effect, and
the Blockchain Administrator shall remain entitled to the benefits thereof, notwithstanding any termination of this Agreement. Further,
notwithstanding the termination or expiration of this Agreement as aforesaid, the Blockchain Administrator shall be entitled to any amounts owed
under Section 4 through the date of termination or expiration, and Section 5 shall continue in force and effect and apply to the Blockchain
Administrator and its representatives as and to the extent applicable.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for termination to 10 days may conflict with the Investment Company Act of 1940, which requires reasonable notice periods to protect the interests of fund shareholders. While the Act doesn't explicitly state a minimum notice period, 10 days could be deemed unreasonable, especially considering the complexities involved in winding down blockchain administration services and potentially finding a replacement administrator. This short notice period could harm the Fund's shareholders.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940, potential violation of fiduciary duty and reasonable care standards

perturbation.original_text:
The Blockchain Administrator agrees to maintain and keep all books, accounts and other records of the Fund that relate to activities
performed by the Blockchain Administrator hereunder and will maintain and keep such books, accounts and records in accordance with the
Investment Company Act. In compliance with the requirements of Rule 31a-3 under the Investment Company Act, the Blockchain Administrator
agrees that all records which it maintains for the Fund shall at all times remain the property of the Fund, shall be readily accessible during normal
business hours, and shall be promptly surrendered upon the termination of the Agreement or otherwise on written request. The Blockchain
Administrator further agrees that all records which it maintains for the Fund pursuant to Rule 31a-1 under the Investment Company Act will be
preserved for the periods prescribed by Rule 31a-2 under the Investment Company Act unless any such records are earlier surrendered as provided
above. Records shall be surrendered in usable machine-readable form. The Blockchain Administrator shall have the right to retain copies of such
records subject to observance of its confidentiality obligations under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
The Blockchain Administrator agrees to maintain and keep all books, accounts and other records of the Fund that relate to activities
performed by the Blockchain Administrator hereunder and will maintain and keep such books, accounts and records in accordance with the
Blockchain Administrator's internal policies. In compliance with the requirements of its internal policies, the Blockchain Administrator
agrees that all records which it maintains for the Fund shall at all times be accessible only with a two-week notice, and will be surrendered within 90 days upon the termination of the Agreement or otherwise on written request. The Blockchain
Administrator further agrees that records which it maintains for the Fund will be
preserved for a period of 1 year. Records shall be surrendered in a non-machine-readable form. The Blockchain Administrator shall have the right to retain copies of such
records subject to observance of its confidentiality obligations under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the record-keeping standards to align with the Blockchain Administrator's "internal policies" instead of the Investment Company Act directly contradicts regulatory requirements. Increasing the surrender time to 90 days, requiring two-week notice for accessibility, limiting preservation to 1 year and providing records in non-machine-readable format are all violations of SEC Rule 31a-2 which mandates specific retention periods and accessibility standards and formats for fund records.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940, SEC Rules 31a-1, 31a-2, and 31a-3

perturbation.original_text:
(a) In full consideration of the provision of the services of the Blockchain Administrator set forth herein, the Fund shall pay the
Blockchain Administrator a fees calculated at the annual rate of 0.20% of the value of the Fund’s average annual net assets. Such fee shall be
accrued daily and paid monthly in arrears.
perturbation.changed_text:
(a) In full consideration of the provision of the services of the Blockchain Administrator set forth herein, the Fund shall pay the
Blockchain Administrator a fees calculated at the annual rate of 0.20% of the value of the Fund’s average annual net assets. Such fee shall be
accrued annually and paid at the discretion of the Blockchain Administrator.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the fee accrual and payment terms to 'accrued annually and paid at the discretion of the Blockchain Administrator' creates a conflict with standard accounting practices and could potentially violate the Investment Company Act's requirements for fair and transparent fee arrangements. The original contract allows monthly payment, but making the payment at Blockchain administrator's discretion is conflict of interest and may not be allowed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940 - potential violation of Section 17(a) and Section 36(b) related to fair and reasonable compensation and fiduciary duty.
